questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.content: Infective constituent in viruses is the protein coat
Prions consist of abnormally folded proteins

questions.explanation:
Virus : Viruses are obligate parasites. In addition to proteins, viruses also contain genetic material that could be either RNA or DNA. No virus contains both RNA and DNA. A virus is a nucleoprotein and the genetic material is infectious.

Viroids: It lacks the protein coat that is found in viruses and hence, the name viroid.

Prions: In modern medicine, certain infectious neurological diseases were found to be transmitted by an agent consisted of abnormally folded protein.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The correct sequence of phases of cell cycle is :
questions.explanation:
The correct sequence of phases of cell cycle is:
G1 $$ \to $$ S $$ \to $$ G2 $$ \to $$ M

G1 (Gap 1) phase : It is the first phase of the growth. It is the stage during which the cell grows and prepares its DNA for replication.

S phase (Synthetic phase) : It is the stage during which DNA synthesis occurs.

G2 phase : In this phase, the cell continues to grow and prepares itself for division.

M Phase : A cell reproduces during the mitotic phase. The mitotic phase has two stages : Karyokinesis and Cytokinesis.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following statements is not correct?

options.content: Lysosomes are formed by the process of packaging in the endoplasmic reticulum.
The hydrolytic enzymes of lysosomes are active under acidic pH.

questions.explanation:
The statement that is not correct is:

Option B: Lysosomes are formed by the process of packaging in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Lysosomes are indeed membrane-bound structures (Option A) that contain numerous hydrolytic enzymes (Option C) which are active under acidic conditions (Option D). However, lysosomes are not formed by the endoplasmic reticulum. Instead, they are formed from vesicles that bud off from the Golgi apparatus. The endoplasmic reticulum is involved in the synthesis of proteins, some of which are destined for lysosomes, but the actual formation and packaging of lysosomes occur at the Golgi apparatus.

Tidal Volume and Expiratory Reserve Volume of an athlete is 500 mL and 1000 mL respectively. What will

Expiratory Capacity (EC) is the total volume of air a person can expire after a normal inspiration. This includes tidal volume and expiratory reserve volume.

Since, Tidal Volume = 500 ml

And Expiratory Reserve Volume = 1000 ml

So, Expiratory Capacity = TV + ERV = 500 + 1000 = 1500 ml

RQ =
CO2 eliminated
O2 consumed

Respiratory quotient of tripalmitin is :

2(C51H98O6) + 145O2 $$ \to $$ 102CO2 + 98H2O + Energy

RQ = $${{102} \over {145}} = 0.7$$

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
What would be the heart rate of a person if the cardiac output is 5L, blood volume in the ventricles at the end
of diastole is 100 mL and at the end of ventricular systole is 50 mL ?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac output = Stroke volume $$ \times $$ Heart rate
Where stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume
= 100 ml – 50 ml
= 50 ml

$$ \therefore $$ 5000 mL = 50 mL × Heart rate

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Heart rate = $${{5000} \over {50}}$$ = 100 beats per minute.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following statements in correct?

options.content: Cornea is convex, transparent layer which is highly vascularised
Cornea consists of dense matrix of collagen and is the most sensitive portion of the eye.
Cornea is an external, Transparent and protective proteinacious covering of the eye-ball
Cornea consists of dense connective tissue of elastin and can repair itself.

questions.explanation:
Option A: This statement is incorrect. The cornea is a transparent, avascular layer at the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber.

Option B: This statement is partially correct. The cornea is made up of a dense matrix of collagen fibers, but it is not the most sensitive portion of the eye. The most sensitive part of the eye is the conjunctiva, which is the thin, transparent layer that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surfaces of the eyelids.

Option C: This statement is correct. The cornea is an external, transparent, and protective proteinaceous covering of the eye-ball.

Option D: This statement is incorrect. The cornea is composed of dense connective tissue of collagen and cannot repair itself. Any injury to the cornea may result in permanent scarring or loss of vision.

questions.content: What is the fate of the male gametes discharged in the synergid?

options.content: One fuses with the egg, other (s) fuse (s) with synergid nucleus.
One fuses with the egg and other fuses with central cell nuclei.
One fuses with the egg, other (s) degenerate (s) in the synergid.

questions.explanation:
In flowering plants,

Out of the two male gametes, one gametes fuses with the nucleus of the nucleus of the egg cell and forms the zygote. The process is known as syngamy.

The other male gamete fuses with the two polar nuclei located in the central cell to form a triploid primary endosperm nucleus (PEN). Since, the process involves the fusion of three haploid nuclei, it is known as triple fusion.

Since two kinds of fusions (syngamy and triple fusion) take place in an embryo sac it is known as double fertilisation

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In Antirrhinum (Snapdragon), a red flower was crossed with a white flower and in F1 generation, pink flowers were obtained. When pink flowers were selfed, the F2 generation showed white, red and pink flowers. Choose the incorrect statement from the following :

options.content: Law of Segregation does not apply in this experiment
This experiment does not follow the Principle of Dominance
Pink colour in F<sub>1</sub> is due to incomplete dominance

questions.explanation:
Inheritance of flower colour in Snapdragon is a classic example for incomplete dominance.

In a cross between true breeding red flower (RR) and true breeding white flower (rr) produced a pink flower (Rr).

When the pink coloured flower of F1 generation was selfed, F2 generation produced plants with red flowers, pink flowers and white flowers in the ratio of 1 : 2 : 1. Here, both red and white flowers were not dominant over each other. Both tried to express their traits and hence an intermediate colour of both red and white resulting in pink colour flowers. Thus, genes for flower colour in snapdragon is an exception of Mendel's first principle i.e. Law of dominance. Law of segregation is universally applicable.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What map unit (Centimorgan) is adopted in the construction of genetic maps?

options.content: A unit of distance between genes on chromosomes, representing 1% cross over.
A unit of distance between genes on chromosomes, representing 50% cross over.
A unit of distance between two expressed genes, representing 10% cross over.
A unit of distance between two expressed genes, representing 100% cross over.

questions.explanation: A centimorgan or map unit is a unit for measuring genetic linkage. It is defined as the distance between chromosome positions (also termed loci or markers) for which the expected average number of intervening chromosomal crossovers in a single generation is 1 percent.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
A gene locus has two alleles A, a. If the frequency of dominant allele A is 0.4, then what will be the
frequency of homozygous dominant, heterozygous and homozygous recessive individuals in the population?
questions.explanation:
Frequency of dominant allele (say p) = 0.4

Frequency of recessive allele (say q) = 1 – 0.4 = 0.6

Frequency of homozygous dominant dividuals (AA) = p2 = (0.4)2 = 0.16

Frequency of heterozygous individuals (Aa) = 2pq = 2(0.4) (0.6) = 0.48

Frequency of homozygous recessive individuals (aa) = q2 = (0.6)2 = 0.36

In a species, the weight of newborn ranges from 2 to 5 kg. 97% of the newborn with an average weight
between 3 to 3.3 kg survive whereas 99% of the infants born with weights from 2 to 2.5 kg or 4.5 to 5kg die.

It shows stabilizing selection as most of the
newborn having average weight between 3 to
3.3 kg survive and babies with less and more
weight have low survival rate. Stabilizing
is a type of natural selection in which the
population mean stabilizes on a particular nonextreme trait value.

and burn agricultural, mining and urbanisation.

process is :
questions.explanation:
According to Haber's process,

N2(g) + 3H2(g) ⇌ 2NH3(g)

2 moles of NH3 uses 3 moles of H2

So, 20 moles of NH3 will use $${3 \over 2}$$ $$ \times $$ 20 moles of H2

= 30 moles of H2

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: 4d, 5p, 5f and 6p orbitals are arranged in the order of decreasing energy. The correct option is :
questions.explanation:
As per Aufbau principle (n + l rule), higher is the value of (n + l), greater will be the energy. When (n + l) values are same then which orbital have higher value of n will have more energy.
4d = 4 + 2 = 6
5p = 5 + 1 = 6
5f = 5 + 3 = 8
6p = 6 + 1 = 7
Hence, the correct order of decreasing energy will
be : 5f > 6p > 5p > 4d.

Li < B < Be < C < O < N < F < Ne
Li < Be < B < C < N < O < F < Ne

questions.explanation:
Ionisation enthalpy increases in a period from left to right, because of increased nuclear charge and decrease in atomic radii. But because of half filled orbitals of Be, N and fully filled orbitals of Ne, stability of those atoms inceases.

So, the correct increasing order of first ionisation enthalpy will be :
Li < B < Be < C < O < N < F < Ne

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following diatomic molecular species has only $$\pi $$ bonds according to Molecular Orbital Theory?
questions.explanation:
$$C_2$$ has 12 electrons.

Moleculer orbital configuration of $$C_2$$

= $${\sigma _{1{s^2}}}\,\sigma _{1{s^2}}^ * \,{\sigma _{2{s^2}}}\,\sigma _{2{s^2}}^ * \,{\pi _{2p_x^2}}\, = \,{\pi _{2p_y^2}}$$

Here no unpaired electron present, so it is diamagnetic.

Here, Bond order = $${{8 - 4} \over 2}$$ = 2. So here two bonds are present. For this two bond formation 4 electrons are required which is present in $${\pi _{2p_x^2}}\, $$ and $$ \,{\pi _{2p_y^2}}$$

So, in C2 molecule, only $$\pi $$ electron occupied the bonding molecular orbital.

Under isothermal condition, a gas at 300 K expands from 0.1 L to 0.25 L against a constant external pressure
of 2 bar. The work done by the gas is [Given that 1 L bar = 100 J]

W = –Pext (V2–V1)

Pext = 2 bar

V1 = 0.1 L

V2 = 0.25 L

W = –2 bar[0.25 – 0.1] L

W = –2 × 0.15 bar L

W = –0.30 bar L

W = (–0.30) × 100 = –30 J

Ca(OH)2 ⇌ Ca+2(aq) + 2OH-(aq)
S 2S
pH = 9 ; pOH = 5 ; [OH–] = 10–5 = 2S

$$ \therefore $$ S = $${{{{10}^{ - 5}}} \over 2}$$

Ksp = [Ca+2] [OH–]2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Ksp = S × (2S)2

Basic buffer is mixture of weak base and salt of weak base with strong acid.

milli mole of HCl = 100 × 0.1 = 10 milli mole

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
For a cell involving one electron $$E_{cell}^\Theta $$ = 0.59 V at 298 K, the equilibrium constant for the cell reaction is :

[Given that $${{2.303RT} \over F}$$ = 0.059 V at T = 298 K ]
questions.explanation:
We know,

Ecell = $$E_{cell}^\Theta $$ - $${{2.303RT} \over {nF}}\log Q$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Ecell = $$E_{cell}^\Theta $$ - $${{0.059} \over n}\log Q$$

(At equilibrium, Ecell = 0 and Q = Keq)

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 0 = $$E_{cell}^\Theta $$ - $${{0.059} \over 1}\log {K_{eq}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\log {K_{eq}} = {{E_{cell}^\Theta } \over {0.059}}$$ = $${{0.59} \over {0.059}}$$ = 10

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Keq = 1010

for 99% completion of the reaction,

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$t = {{4.606} \over k}$$

questions.content: A force F = 20 + 10y acts on a particle in y-direction where F is in newton and y in meter. Work done by this force to move the particle from y = 0 to y = 1 m is :

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A hollow metal sphere of radius R is uniformly charged. The electric field due to the sphere at a distance r from the centre :

options.content: zero as r increases for r < R, decreases as r  increases for r > R
zero as r increases for r < R, increases as r increases for r > R.
decreases as r increases for r < R and for  r > R.
increases as r increases for r < R and for r > R.

questions.explanation:
For inside (r $$<$$ R)

Apply, Gauss law,

$$\oint {{E_{in}}} .\overrightarrow {dS} $$ = $${{{q_{en}}} \over {{\varepsilon _0}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Ein = 0 [ As qen = 0 ]

For outside (r $$>$$ R)

$$\oint {{{\overrightarrow E }_{out}}} .\overrightarrow {dS} = {{{q_{en}}} \over {{\varepsilon _0}}}$$

Here, qen = Q

So, Eout.4$$\pi $$r2 = $${Q \over {{\varepsilon _0}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ Eout $$ \propto $$ $${1 \over {{r^2}}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
Six similar bulbs are connected as shown in the figure with a DC source of emf E, and zero internal resistance.

The ratio of power consumption by the bulbs when (i) all are glowing and (ii) in the situation when two from section A and one from section B are glowing, will be :
questions.explanation:
(i) When all bulbs are glowing, from the given figure.
Equivalent resistance, Req = $${R \over 3} + {R \over 3} = {{2R} \over 3}$$

Initial Power, (Pi) = $${{3{E^2}} \over {2R}}$$ ......(1)

(ii) When two section A and one from section B are glowing.

Req = $${R \over 2} + R$$ = $${{3R} \over 2}$$

Final Power, (Pf) = $${{2{E^2}} \over {3R}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $${{{P_i}} \over {{P_f}}} = {{3{E^2}} \over {2R}} \times {{3R} \over {2{E^2}}}$$ = 9 : 4

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A cylinderical conductor of radius R is carrying a constant current. The plot of the magnitude of the magnetic field. B with the distane d from the centre of the conductor, is correctly represented by the figure :

The magnetic field inside conductor is given as

If, straight line passing through origin, at surface (d = R)

B = $${{{\mu _0}} \over {2\pi }}{i \over R}$$

B = $${{{\mu _0}} \over {2\pi }}{i \over d}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ B $$ \propto $$ $${1 \over d}$$

questions.explanation:
Since, net displacement in complete cycle ∆y = 0

So, Average velocity

=
Displacement
Time travel

= $${{{y_f} - {y_i}} \over T}$$ = $${{\Delta y} \over T} = {0 \over T} = 0$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A solid cylinder of mass 2 kg and radius 4 cm is rotating about its axis at the rate of 3 rpm. The torque required to stop after 2$$\pi $$ revolutions is :
questions.explanation:
Acccording to work energy theorem,

W = $${1 \over 2}\left( {\omega _f^2 - \omega _i^2} \right)$$

Given that,

$$\theta $$ = 2$$\pi $$ revolution/minute

$$\theta $$ = 2$$\pi $$ $$ \times $$ 2$$\pi $$ = 4$$\pi $$2 rad

$${\omega _i} = 3 \times {{2\pi } \over {60}}$$ rad/s

$${\omega _f} = 0$$ rad/s

By putting the value of $${\omega _f}$$ and $${\omega _i}$$, we get

- $$\tau $$$$\theta $$ = $${1 \over 2} \times {1 \over 2}m{r^2}\left( {0 - \omega _i^2} \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\tau $$ = $$ - {{{1 \over 2} \times {1 \over 2} \times 2 \times \left( {4 \times {{10}^{ - 2}}} \right) \times {{\left( { - 3 \times {{2\pi } \over {60}}} \right)}^2}} \over {4{\pi ^2}}}$$

= 2 $$ \times $$ 10-6 Nm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A 800 turn coil of effective area 0.05 m<sup>2</sup> is kept.  perpendicular to a magnetic filed 5 × 10<sup>–5</sup> T. When the plane of the coil is rotated by 90<sup>o</sup> around any of its coplanar axis in 0.1 s, the emf induced in the coil will be :
questions.explanation:
Given N = 800, A = 0.05 m2 , B = 5 × 10–5 T

$$\Delta $$t = 0.15 s

We know, e = $$ - {{\left( {{\phi _f} - {\phi _i}} \right)} \over {\Delta t}}$$

= $$ - {{\left( {0 - NBA} \right)} \over {\Delta t}}$$

= $${{800 \times 5 \times {{10}^{ - 5}} \times 5 \times {{10}^{ - 2}}} \over {0.1}}$$

= 0.02 V

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A block of mass 10 kg is in contact against the inner wall of a hollow cylindrical drum of radius 1 m. The coefficient of friction between the block and the inner wall of the cylinder is 0.1. The minimum angular velocity needed for the cylinder to keep the block stationary when the cylinder is vertical and rotating about its axis, will be : (g = 10 m/s<sup>2</sup>)
questions.explanation:
fL = $$\mu $$N = $$\mu $$mr$${\omega ^2}$$

fs = mg

As, fs $$ \le $$ fL

$$ \Rightarrow $$ mg $$ \le $$ $$\mu $$mr$${\omega ^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\omega \ge \sqrt {{g \over {\mu r}}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${\omega _{\min }} \ge \sqrt {{{10} \over {0.1 \times 1}}} $$ = 10

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The speed of a swimmer in still water is 20 m/s. The speed of river water is 10 m/s and is flowing due east. If he is standing on the south bank and wishes to cross the river along the shortest path, the angle at which he should make his strokes w.r.t. north is given by :
questions.explanation:
VSR = 20 m/s

VRG = 10 m/s

$${\overrightarrow V _{SG}} = {\overrightarrow V _{SR}} + {\overrightarrow V _{RG}}$$

sin $$\theta $$ = $$\left| {{{{{\overrightarrow V }_{RG}}} \over {{{\overrightarrow V }_{SR}}}}} \right|$$ = $${{10} \over {20}}$$ = $${1 \over 2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ θ = 30° west-side

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
The displacement of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is given by

y = A0 + A sin$$\omega $$t + B cos$$\omega $$t.

Then the amplitude of its oscillation is given by :
questions.explanation:
From the given displacement

y = A0 + A sin$$\omega $$t + B cos$$\omega $$t.

Let assume, y - A0 = $$\gamma $$

$$\gamma $$ = A sin$$\omega $$t + B cos$$\omega $$t

= $$\sqrt {{A^2} + {B^2}} \sin \left( {\omega t + \phi } \right)$$

which is S.H.M

$$ \therefore $$ Resultant amplitude of the particle,

= $$\sqrt {{A^2} + {B^2}} $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
In an experiment, the percentage of error occurred in the measurement of physical quantities A, B, C and D are 1%, 2 %, 3 %and 4 % respectively. Then the maximum percentage of error in the measurement X, where
X = $${{{A^2}{B^{1/2}}} \over {{C^{1/3}}{D^3}}}$$, will be :
questions.explanation:
Given,

X = $${{{A^2}{B^{1/2}}} \over {{C^{1/3}}{D^3}}}$$

$${{\Delta X} \over X} = {{2\Delta A} \over A} + {1 \over 2}{{\Delta B} \over B} + {1 \over 3}{{\Delta C} \over C} + 3{{\Delta D} \over D}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${{\Delta X} \over X} \times 100 = 2\left( {1\% } \right) + {1 \over 2}\left( {2\% } \right) + {1 \over 3}\left( {3\% } \right) + 3\left( {4\% } \right)$$ = 16 %

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An electron is accelerated through a potential difference of 10,000 V. Its de Broglie wavelength is (nearly) : (m<sub>e</sub>  = 9 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>–31</sup> kg)
questions.explanation:
Expression for an electron accelerated through a potential V is given as

$$\lambda $$ = $${{12.27} \over {\sqrt V }}\mathop A\limits^o $$

= $${{12.27 \times {{10}^{ - 10}}} \over {\sqrt {10000} }}$$

= 12.2 × 10–12 m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A mass m is attached to a thin wire and whirled in a vertical circle. The wire is most likely to break when :

options.content: inclined at an angle of 60<sup>o</sup> from vertical
the mass is at the lowest point
the mass is at the highest point

questions.explanation:
Apply Newtons's 2nd law for equation of motion

T - mg cos $$\theta $$ = $${{m{v^2}} \over R}$$

T will be maximum when $$\theta $$ = 0°,

When mass is at lowest point the chance of breaking is maximum.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A copper rod of 88 cm and an aluminium rod of unknown length have their increase in length independent of increase in tmperature. The length of aluminium rod is : ($$\alpha $$<sub>Cu</sub> = 1.7 × 10<sup>–5</sup> K<sup>–1</sup> and 
 $$\alpha $$<sub>Al</sub> = 2.2 × 10<sup>–5</sup> K<sup>–1</sup>)
questions.explanation:
At any temperature

$${\left( {\Delta l} \right)_{Cu}} = {\left( {\Delta l} \right)_{Al}}$$

$${l_{Cu}}{\alpha _{Cu}}\Delta T = {l_{Al}}{\alpha _{Al}}\Delta T$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 88 $$ \times $$ 1.7 $$ \times $$ 10-5 = $${l_{Al}}$$ $$ \times $$ 2.2 × 10–5

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${l_{Al}}$$ = 68 cm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two particles A and B are moving in uniform circular motion in concentric circles of radii r<sub>A</sub> and r<sub>B</sub> with speed v<sub>A</sub> and v<sub>B</sub> respecitively. Their time period of rotation is the same. The ratio of angular speed of A to that of B will be :
questions.explanation:
Since, the time period for both the particle in same So, TA = TB = T

Angular velocity for A, ($${\omega _A}$$) = $${{2\pi } \over {{T_A}}}$$

Angular velocity for B, ($${\omega _B}$$) = $${{2\pi } \over {{T_B}}}$$

Now, the required ratio is

$${{{\omega _A}} \over {{\omega _B}}} = {{{T_B}} \over {{T_A}}} = {T \over T} = 1$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Ionized hydrogen atoms and $$\alpha $$-particles with same momenta enters perpendicular to a constant magnetic field, B. The ratio of their radii of their paths r<sub>H</sub> : r<sub>$$\alpha $$</sub> will be :
questions.explanation:
Radius of the path (r) = $${{mv} \over {qB}}$$ = $${p \over {qB}}$$

So, the radius for H-atom rH = $${p \over {eB}}$$

The radius for $$\alpha $$ particle r$$\alpha $$ = $${p \over {2eB}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $${{{r_H}} \over {{r_\alpha }}} = {{{p \over {eB}}} \over {{p \over {2eB}}}}$$ = $${2 \over 1}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When a block of mass M is suspended by a long wire of length L, the length of the wire becomes (L + $$l$$). The elastic potential energy stored in the extended wire is :
questions.explanation:
Elastic potential energy

U = $${1 \over 2}$$ (work done due to gravity)

= $${1 \over 2}$$Mgl

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The work done to raise a mass m from the surface of the earth to a height h, which is equal to the radius of the earth, is :
questions.explanation:
Initial potential energy at Earths surface is

Ui = $$ - {{GMm} \over R}$$

Final potential energy at height h = R :

Uf = $$ - {{GMm} \over 2R}$$

work done = change in PE

w = Uf - Ui

= $${{GMm} \over 2R}$$

= $${{g{R^2}m} \over {2R}}$$

= $${1 \over 2}$$mgR

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In total internal reflection when the angle of incidence is equal to the critical angle for the pair of media in contact, what will be angle of refraction?
questions.explanation:
Let ic be the critical angle.

Hence, at i = ic, refracted ray grazes with the surface.

So, angle of refraction is 90°.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For a p-type semiconductor, which of the following statements is true?

options.content: Holes are the majority carriers and trivalent atoms are the dopants.
Holes are the majority carriers and pentavalent atoms are the dopants.
Electrons are the majority carriers and pentavalent atoms are the dopants
Electrons are the majority carriers and trivalent atoms are the dopants.

questions.explanation: In p-type semiconductor, an intrinsic semiconductor is doped with trivalent impurities, that creates deficiencies of valence electrons called holes which are majority charge carriers.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two point charges A and B, having charges +Q and – Q respectively, are placed at certain distance apart and force acting between them is F. If 25% charge of A is transferred to B, then force between the charges becomes :
questions.explanation:
Initially F = $$ - {{K{Q^2}} \over {{r^2}}}$$

If 25% of charge of A transferred to B then after the transformation of charge.

qA = $$Q - {Q \over 4}$$ = $${{3Q} \over 4}$$

and qb = -Q + $${Q \over 4}$$ = $$ - {{3Q} \over 4}$$

New force, F1 = $${{K\left( {{{3Q} \over 4}} \right)\left( { - {{3Q} \over 4}} \right)} \over {{r^2}}} $$

$$= - {9 \over {16}}{{K{Q^2}} \over {{r^2}}}$$

= $${{9F} \over {16}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: $$\alpha $$-particale consists of :
questions.explanation: Since, $$\alpha $$-particle is equivalent to He-atom nucleus, hence it has two protons and two neutrons only.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Body A of mass 4m moving with speed u collides with another body B of mass 2 m, at rest. The collision is head on and elastic in nature. After the collision the fraction of energy lost by the colliding body A is :
questions.explanation:
As linear momentum is conserved before and after the collision,

$$ \therefore $$ 4m $$ \times $$ u = 4m $$ \times $$ v1 + 2m $$ \times $$ v2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 2u = 2v1 + v2 ......(1)

As collision is elastic so e = 1

We know, e = $${{{v_2} - {v_1}} \over {{u_1} - {u_2}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 1 = $${{{v_2} - {v_1}} \over {u - 0}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ u = v2 - v1 ....(2)

Subtractiong (2) from (1), we get

u = 3v1

$$ \Rightarrow $$ v1 = $${u \over 3}$$

After the collision the fraction of energy lost by the colliding body A is

= $${{{1 \over 2}\left( {4m} \right){u^2} - {1 \over 2}\left( {4m} \right){{\left( {{u \over 3}} \right)}^2}} \over {{1 \over 2}\left( {4m} \right){u^2}}}$$

= $${{1 - {1 \over 9}} \over 1}$$ = $${8 \over 9}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A body weight 200 N on the surface of earth. How much will it weight half way down to the centre of the earth?
questions.explanation:
Accelerattion due to gravity at a depth d from surface of Earth

$$g$$' = $$g\left( {1 - {d \over R}} \right)$$ ....(1)

Multiplying by mass 'm' on both sides of equation (1)

m$$g$$' = m$$g\left( {1 - {d \over R}} \right)$$

= $$200\left( {1 - {R \over {2R}}} \right)$$    ($$ \because $$ $${d = {R \over 2}}$$)

= $${{200} \over 2} = 100$$ N

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Pick the wrong answer in the context with rainbow.

options.content: An observer can see a rainbow when his front is towards the sun.
Rainbow is a combined effect of dispersion refraction and reflection of sunlight.
When the light rays undergo two internal reflections in a water drop, a secondary rainbow is formed.
The order of colours is reversed in the secondary rainbow.

questions.explanation: When observer faces infront of Sun. He will not observe rainbow.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A disc of radius 2 m and mass 100 kg rolls on a horizontal floor. Its centre of mass has speed of 20 cm/s. How much work is needed to stop it?
questions.explanation:
$$\omega = {V \over R} = {{0.2} \over 2} = $$ 0.1 rad/sec

Apply the law of conservation of energy,

Work required = change in kinetic energy

Since, final KE = 0

And, initial KE = $${1 \over 2}m{v^2} + {1 \over 2}I{\omega ^2}$$

= $${1 \over 2}m{v^2} + {1 \over 2}{{M{l^2}} \over 2}{\omega ^2}$$

= $${1 \over 2}\left( {100} \right){\left( {0.2} \right)^2} + {1 \over 2}{{100 \times {{\left( 2 \right)}^2}} \over 2}{\left( {0.1} \right)^2}$$

= 1 + $${1 \over 2} \times 4$$ = 3 J

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A small hole of area of cross-section 2 mm<sup>2</sup> present  near the bottom of a fully filled open tank of height 2 m. Taking g = 10 m/s<sup>2</sup>, the rate of flow of water through the open hole would be nearly :
questions.explanation:
volume flow rate = Av = A$$\sqrt {2gh} $$

= 2 $$ \times $$ 10-6 $$ \times $$ $$\sqrt {2 \times 10 \times 2} $$

= 2 $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 3.14 $$ \times $$ 10-6 m3/s

= 12.56 $$ \times $$ 10-6 m3/s

= 12.6 $$ \times $$ 10-6 m3/s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A parallel plate capacitor  of capacitance 20 $$\mu $$F is being charged by a voltage source whose potential is changing at the rate of 3V/s. The conduction current through the connecting wires, and the displacement current through the plates of the capacitor, would be, respectively :
questions.explanation:
As, q = CV

Differentiating above equation w.r.t. t, we get

$${{dq} \over {dt}} = C{{dV} \over {dt}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ ic = $$C{{dV} \over {dt}}$$ [As i = $${{dq} \over {dt}}$$]

= 20 $$ \times $$ 10-6 $$ \times $$ 3

= 60 $$ \times $$ 10-6 A = 60$$\mu $$A

Also, conduction current in wires is equal to displacement current between the plates of capacitor.

$$ \therefore $$ id = ic = 60 $$\mu $$A

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When an object is shot from the bottom of a long smooth inclined plane kept at an angle 60<sup>o</sup> with horizontal, it can travel a distance x<sub>1</sub> along the plane. But when the inclination is decreased to 30<sup>o</sup> and the same object is shot with the same velocity, it can travel x<sub>2</sub> distance. Then x<sub>1</sub> : x<sub>2</sub> will be :
questions.explanation:
Assume initial velocity = u


In first case, Moved distance, (x1) = $${{{u^2}} \over {2g\sin {{60}^o}}}$$

In second case, Moved distance, (x2) = $${{{u^2}} \over {2g\sin {{30}^o}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $${{{x_1}} \over {{x_2}}} = {{\sin {{30}^o}} \over {\sin {{60}^o}}}$$ = $${{1 \times 2} \over {2 \times \sqrt 3 }}$$ = $${1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The unit of thermal conductivity is :
questions.explanation:
We know,

Heat transfer (Q) = KA$$\left( {{{\Delta T} \over {\Delta x}}} \right)$$$$ \times $$t

Here, K is the coefficient of thermal conductivity

J = (K)m2$${{kelvin} \over m}$$$$ \times $$ s

$$ \therefore $$ Unit of K = Wm–1 K–1

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The total energy of an electron in an atom in an orbit is –3.4 eV. Its kinetic and potential energies are, respectively.
questions.explanation:
Apply Bohr's Atomic model for H-atom

KE = –T.E and PE = 2T.E

Given, T.E = –3.4 eV

$$ \therefore $$ KE = +3.4 eV and PE = -6.8 eV

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Which of the following acts as a circuit protection device?
questions.explanation: Fuse is the protective device because of low melting point of the wire that can save other device on heating.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A soap bubble, having radius of 1 mm, is blown from a detergent solution having a surface tension of 2.5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>–2</sup> N/m. The pressure inside the bubble equals at a point Z<sub>0</sub> below the free surface of water in a container. Taking g = 10 m/s<sup>2</sup>, density of water = 10<sup>3</sup> kg/m<sup>3</sup>, the value of Z<sub>0</sub> is :
questions.explanation:
P = P0 + $$\rho $$gZ0 .........(i)

Also, P = P0 + $${{4T} \over R}$$ .....(ii)

From (i) and (ii),

$$\rho $$gZ0 = $${{4T} \over R}$$

$$ \therefore $$ Z0 = $${{4T} \over {\rho gR}}$$

= $${{4 \times 2.5 \times {{10}^{ - 2}}} \over {{{10}^3} \times 10 \times {{10}^{ - 3}}}}$$

= 10-2 m = 1 cm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two similar thin equi-convex lenses, of focal length f each, are kept coaxially in contact with each other such that the focal length of the combination is F<sub>1</sub>. When the space between the two lenses is filled with glycerin (which has the same refractive index (m = 1.5) as that of glass) then the equivalent focal length is F<sub>2</sub>. The ratio F<sub>1</sub> : F<sub>2</sub> will be :
questions.explanation:
Equivalent focal length (in air) $${1 \over {{F_1}}} = {1 \over f} + {1 \over f} = {2 \over f}$$

When glycerin is filled inside, glycerin lens behaves like a diverging lens of focal length (–f)

$${1 \over {{F_2}}} = {1 \over f} + {1 \over f} - {1 \over f} = {1 \over f}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $${{{F_1}} \over {{F_2}}} = {1 \over 2}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In which of the following devices, the eddy current effect is not used?
questions.explanation: Eddy current effect is not used in case of electric heater because it works on Joule's heating effect.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two parallel infinite line charges with linear charge densities +$$\lambda $$ C/m and -$$\lambda $$ C/m are placed at a distance of 2R in free space. What is the electric field mid-way between the two line charges?
questions.explanation:
$${\overrightarrow E _{net}} = {\overrightarrow E _1} + {\overrightarrow E _2}$$

= $${\lambda \over {2\pi {\varepsilon _0}R}}$$ + $${\lambda \over {2\pi {\varepsilon _0}R}}$$

= $${\lambda \over {\pi {\varepsilon _0}R}}$$ N/C

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle moving with velocity $$\overrightarrow V $$ is acted by three forces shown by the vector triangle PQR. The velocity of the particle will :

options.content: change according to the smallest force $$\overrightarrow {QR} $$

questions.explanation:
From the given diagram, the forces are forming closed loop in same order.

$$ \therefore $$ Fnet = $$\overrightarrow 0 $$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$m{{dv} \over {dt}}$$ = $$\overrightarrow 0 $$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\overrightarrow v $$ = constant.
